title: Daily Temperatures
patternTriggers: Need number of days until warmer = Next greater element variant. Use monotonic decreasing stack with indices to track distance.

approaches.name: Brute Force - Nested Loops
approaches.intuition: For each day, scan forward to find the next warmer day and calculate the distance.
approaches.approach: For each day i, iterate through days i+1 to n-1 until finding warmer temperature.

approaches.name: Monotonic Stack - Right to Left
approaches.intuition: Process from right to left. Stack stores indices of potential warmer days. Pop cooler days.
approaches.approach: Traverse right to left, maintain monotonic decreasing stack (by temperature). Find next warmer in stack.
steps: While stack not empty and temperatures[stack.top()] <= temperatures[i]:

complexity.timeExplanation: Each index pushed and popped at most once

approaches.name: Monotonic Stack - Left to Right - Optimal
approaches.intuition: Process left to right. When we find warmer day, update all cooler previous days in stack. More intuitive.
approaches.approach: Traverse left to right. For each day, pop and update all cooler days from stack. Push current day.
steps: While stack not empty and temperatures[i] > temperatures[stack.top()]:

complexity.timeExplanation: Each index pushed and popped at most once
complexity.spaceExplanation: Stack stores indices, worst case all indices

commonMistakes: Storing temperatures instead of indices in stack
Using <= instead of < when comparing temperatures
Forgetting to calculate distance (j - i) instead of just storing j
Confusion about stack order (should maintain decreasing temperatures)
hints: This is a variant of Next Greater Element with distance calculation
Store indices in stack, not temperatures
Left to right approach is more intuitive - update results as you find answers
Stack maintains monotonic decreasing order of temperatures
When popping, calculate distance: current_index - popped_index
